bestBHT.bht: When Jesus spoke, there was a violent dissension among the people: some took up His cause while others wished to lay hands on Him. Many said, Of a truth, acknowledging Him as the Messiah. A clear split had arisen, with some believing Him to be a prophet, others asserting Him to be the Christ, and still others objecting on account of His background. This division caused turmoil and disagreement among the crowd, highlighting the impact and controversy of Jesus' words.

Henry Alford: The word rendered division implies a violent dissension,—some taking up His cause, some wishing to lay hands on Him.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Many...when they heard this...said, Of a truth, &c.—The only wonder is they did not all say it.
Marvin Vincent: There was a division [σχισμα εγενετο] . More correctly, as Rev., "there arose a division." See on 1 3.
Archibald T. Robertson: A division (σχισμα). A clear split. See Matthew 9:16 for the word from σχιζω, to rend. Used again in John 9:16; John 10:19.
John Gill: Some, though they did not go so far as to believe him to be the Messiah, yet took him to be a prophet, and a very extraordinary one.
Others made no difficulty to assert him to be the Christ.
Others objected to it on account of the country from whence he came.

As Jesus spoke, a violent dissension erupted among the people, resulting in a clear split in their beliefs. Some recognized Him as the Messiah when they heard Him, while others desired to seize Him. Many acknowledged His authority, proclaiming, Of a truth. This division displayed the diverse opinions within the crowd: some viewed Him as a prophet, others boldly declared Him to be the Christ, and still others raised objections based on His origins. Thus, the contentious disagreement revealed the profound impact and controversy surrounding Jesus' words.
